nodes.text: Expected utility theory can be interpreted as optimization of time-average growth under appropriate wealth dynamics by identifying the utility function with the ergodicity transformation
Ergodicity economics (EE) postulates agents maximize the time-average growth rate of wealth (growth optimality) rather than expectation values

There exists a correspondence such that the ergodicity transformation in EE can be identified as the utility function in expected utility theory (EUT), making expected-utility maximization equivalent to time-average growth maximization for a class of wealth dynamics

For EUT to be equivalent to optimization over time, the utility u(x) must follow an additive stochastic process with stationary increments; in continuous-path models u(t) must be a Brownian motion with drift du = a_u dt + b_u dW

Theorem: For any invertible utility function u(x) there exists a corresponding class of wealth stochastic differential equations dx = a_x(x) dt + b_x(x) dW such that maximizing expected changes in u is equivalent to maximizing the time-average growth rate under that dynamic

Examples: u(x)=x corresponds to additive Brownian wealth; u(x)=ln x corresponds to geometric Brownian wealth; u(x)=sqrt(x) yields a mixed additive-multiplicative SDE with noise amplitude proportional to sqrt(x)

Derivation via Ito calculus: imposing du dynamics with constant coefficients yields relations bu = b_x(x) u'(x) and au = a_x(x) u'(x) + 1/2 b_x(x)^2 u''(x), producing consistency conditions (explicit formula for a_x in terms of b_x) that determine when a utility exists for a given dynamic

If u follows the Brownian motion in (du = a_u dt + b_u dW) then the long-time limit of the rate of change of u equals the time-average growth rate and equals the expectation-rate for u, establishing ergodicity of the observable r = delta u / delta t

Because wealth dynamics are exogenous, the corresponding utility function predicted by EE implies that observed risk preferences are determined by underlying wealth dynamics and will change if dynamics change
Empirical evidence: controlled experiments with manipulable wealth dynamics support EE predictions that dynamics strongly determine preferences

Mathematical consequence: invertibility required to map utility to dynamics implies utility functions should be unbounded for a clean formalism; bounded utilities are problematic because they are noninvertible and can produce finite-time singularities

Limitation: If a wealth process does not admit an ergodicity transformation (i.e., u for which increments are stationary and independent) then EUT cannot be interpreted as optimization over time for that process

Conclusion: The EE-EUT correspondence gives a theoretical basis to select utility functions from specified wealth dynamics and provides a physical interpretation of utility-based models, removing psychological arbitrariness
